35.text:
Seeing London is one thing, but to get the
most out of the city you have to engage with it

41.text:
immerse yourself in its energy and
explore.

46.text: Venture off the tourist path and you never know what you might find.

51.text:
This is the Virgin Atlantic Guide to making
the most of our beloved city.

77.text: Accommodation in London in exemplary and often Anglo-centric. Here’s some British hospitality at its best.

85.text:
A former car park in the heart
of the city has been transformed into a hotel described as one of the most glamorous in the world.

94.text:
The Soho Hotel has an amazing bar and restaurant with the best of the rest on
its doorstep.

102.text: If an oasis of calm in the thick of it appeals, then this is the hotel for you.

115.text: Once home to Hogarth, Dean Street Townhouse is a love letter to the decadence of the famous English painter.

123.text: The very hip address is still pulling in the creative crowds

127.text: and its all day dining room is surrounded by more contemporary works.

132.text:
The hotel offers great value for such
high-end luxury.

137.text: Alternatively, there can be few places to stay quite as unique as Living Architecture’s city dwelling.

145.text: The boat, perched on top of the Queen Elizabeth Hall was created to offer guests a place of refuge.

151.text: Living Architecture have other one-off residencies to rent out of town.

161.text: Staying further out of the centre can reduce hotel rates and provide quirky and eccentric insights into London life.

169.text: The Tube makes light work of getting you back into town.

175.text:
In the heart of leafy West London you’ll
find High Road House.

179.text: The boutique hotel is an outpost of the ever-cool Soho House Group

184.text: and the well-priced rooms come with entry into the private Members’ Club.

190.text: The very fashionable 40 Winks in the East End is a fantastical place to lay your head for the night.

198.text:
Staying is made all the more special by the tireless commitment of the B&B’s
owner, David Carter.

207.text: This B&B feels just like staying in a boutique hotel but without the hefty price tag.

221.text:
You can get around London as leisurely or
as quickly as you like.

224.text: The Tube is the best option if you want to zip around and make the most of your stay.

229.text: But if you’ve got time on your hands, the bus routes still offer the best chance to see all the sights.

234.text: A couple of iconic old-style Routemaster buses now run as heritage routes.

240.text: Visit Transport for London’s website for more information about the best way to get around the city.

255.text:
London hotels are still worth a visit if you
already have your accommodation sorted.

265.text: Head to The Sanderson for a decadent take on afternoon tea.

269.text: At the Mad Hatter’s Tea Party you’re invited to tumble down the rabbit hole and experience tea and cakes with a Lewis Carol twist.

279.text:
Old-school glamour waits for you at
the American Bar at the Savoy Hotel.

284.text: World-famous cocktails have been mixed in this classic Art Deco joint since the late 19th Century.

293.text:
And for the best views, dine at Galvin at
Windows at the Hilton, Park Lane.

298.text: The restaurant is perched at the top of the hotel and has a jaw-dropping birds eye view over the city.

308.text:
The restored St Pancras Hotel is a beautiful
example of Victorian Gothic architecture.

316.text: Non-residents can take a tour around the building with the hotel’s guide,

319.text: or visit a traditional barber on the platform for a haircut with a difference!

329.text:
Great plans are made in the great British
pub. They are an integral part of British culture

334.text:
so much more than a place to quench
your thirst.

338.text: Gordon’s Wine Bar is thought to be the oldest wine bar in town and has been established in its present form since 1890.

345.text:
The cosy setting has not changed in
decades and historical references to the past adorn every wall.

352.text: Sherrys, Madeiras and Ports and served from the barrel.

356.text: The wine bar was the former home of London diarist Samuel Pepys.

361.text: The Dove is one of the most ancient settings to enjoy a good pint and a lazy afternoon along the banks of the River Thames.

369.text: Over the years the pub has been a frequent haunt of many a writer, including Graham Greene and Ernest Hemingway.

377.text: The perfect pit stop after a picturesque gambol along the riverbank.

384.text: Nestled along the tow path of the Grand Union Canal, the Waterway pub feels a world away from the West End

390.text: but is only a few stops from Oxford Circus on the Bakerloo line.

394.text: Its sister restaurant, The Summerhouse, located on a nearby houseboat, is famous for its delicious seafood.

403.text: Food on the go is all the rage in London and there are plenty of places to sample some top notch street food.

408.text: Grab a plate and head for the nearest open space for an impromptu al fresco dining experience.

418.text: Whole areas have been taken over by a new generation of independent food lovers and producers.

424.text: Stalls and shops are popping up all over the place, peddling the finest ingredients and culinary creations.

432.text: Brick Lane’s Sunday UpMarket is home to one of the most exciting food scenes in London.

438.text:
It’s an experience like no other as vintage stalls, music sellers and crafts pepper The
Old Truman Brewery.

445.text: Industrious caterers serve up the most amazing dishes from all over the world. This is multicultural London at its best.

455.text:
Pizza East, nearby, is a modern take
on the pizzeria.

458.text: Based in the Tea Building in Shoreditch,  it’s a more leisurely alternative to the food offered at the stalls.

465.text: The restaurant also serves brunch at the weekend.

471.text: Borough Market remains London’s most renowned food market and offers exceptional British and international produce.

478.text: Check out the market website before making a visit for information

481.text: on up-coming events and some amazing recipes from local traders. The market runs from Thursday to Saturday every week.

497.text:
For amazing Moorish-influenced
cuisine, head to the food haven Exmouth Market

502.text:
where you’ll find the much coveted Moro.
For a more informal dining affair pop next

507.text:
door to Morito for the most delicious Tapas
in town.

512.text: It goes without saying that London is a shopper’s paradise.

517.text: Here’s our guide to London’s hippest shopping postcodes!

522.text: Put on your comfiest walking shoes and head to the backstreets of the West End.

528.text: The Bond Street area attracts the very best in boutique shopping.

533.text: Many of the suppliers to the bigger department stores can be found here.

539.text: Grays Antiques Market is well worth an afternoon browse.

543.text: If vintage isn’t your thing, there are plenty of collector’s items and one-off treasures on offer.

553.text: Dover Street Market is dedicated to fashion and design.

557.text: Cutting edge brands are displayed like art installations at this ground-breaking store.

570.text: Carnaby, Soho and the surrounding streets are littered with contemporary and quirky boutiques.

577.text:
Check out Lazy Oaf for snazzy art-inspired
stationary and textiles.

583.text: As well as looking good, their wares are guaranteed to make you smile!

589.text:
In the heart of Soho you’ll find YMC, master producers of unique workwear-inspired
clothing.

598.text: The brand’s name aptly stands for You Must Create.

602.text:
The collections are stunning
and include wardrobe staples that are designer spec at high street prices.

611.text:
Marylebone High Street is a village-like hub
in the heart of the West End.

616.text: Nestled amongst the cafes and bars you’ll find some top purchases.

621.text: Daunt Books is a literary step back in time. The Edwardian building could make anyone feel like a scholar as they flick through their well-stocked shelves.

631.text: Artisan suppliers to Selfridges, Cire Trudon have their flagship store here.

639.text: And for all things cheesy, make a visit to La Fromagerie, one of many food specialist shops dotted along the high street.

648.text: And Paul Smith, the brave knight of British design has a shop here too.

657.text:
West side of the city there’s great shopping
to be had around Portobello Road and the surrounding area.

663.text:
Independent fashion doesn’t get much
better than at Wolf & Badger.

667.text: Up and coming designers can showcase their wares here to style-savvy West Londoners.

679.text: Chocolate lovers can get their fix with award-winning chocolatiers Melt.

684.text: The chocolates are crafted in store and the tempting aromas make it all the more impossible to leave empty handed.

692.text: Merchant Archive describes itself as a vintage and contemporary lifestyle shop

697.text: that from humble beginnings now attracts London’s top stylists, fashion designers and celebrities alike.

715.text:
The achingly-hip East End of town has a lot
more to offer than skinny jeans and geeky glasses!

723.text:
Broadway Market is one of the most
heart-warming places to be on a sunny Saturday afternoon.

729.text: The stall holders design most of the wares on offer so you can get the full backstory of what you’re buying.

741.text: One such designer is Karin Andreasson, a jewellery and headpiece designer selling at the market every weekend.

752.text: Old Spitalfields is becoming ever more commercialised but the former fruit and veg market is such a beautiful space to browse,

759.text: it’s still well worth a visit.

761.text: It continues to draw an eclectic crowd that rummage through the diverse range of goods on offer.

771.text: Folk at Brick Lane is just one of a handful of brilliant, smaller labels in the areas.

777.text: They focus on traditional British tailoring and quality finishes,

780.text: a welcome antidote to the mass-marketed looks to be found elsewhere on the high street.

791.text: London has so much on offer to enlighten and entertain.

795.text: At any one time, there are infinite possibilities to be amused, dazzled and delighted!

801.text: Time Out magazine remains the best source of up-to-date information about what’s going on and when.

812.text: The West End will always be home to London theatre but for a more intimate experience head to Shepherd’s Bush.

818.text: Located in a former library, The Bush Theatre is world-famous for pioneering new plays and nurturing raw talent.

825.text: The theatre boasts a beautiful bar and café and has ignited the careers of some amazing actors.

836.text: South of the river you will find the ground-breaking Menier Chocolate Factory Theatre.

841.text: A visit here offers every chance to catch a future West End hit.

845.text: The much loved fringe theatre also has an award-winning restaurant.

851.text: Sadlers Wells has been a place of entertainment for over 300 years.

856.text: It is now the UK’s leading dance house, dedicated to bringing the very best of international and UK dance to London audiences.

864.text: They produce the most amazing shows here.

868.text: On the north side of the river, across from the Southbank, is Somerset House.

872.text: The formal naval residence has become a glorious backdrop and centre of excellence for art, music and entertainment.

880.text: The Courtauld Gallery is home to masterpieces that could hold their own in any world-renowned gallery,

886.text:
and the central courtyard stages
everything from music gigs to open-air cinema nights.

895.text:
Nourish your soul and head out on two feet
to the Southbank Centre.

899.text: A walk along the river here will take you through some of the most culturally exciting parts of the city.

905.text: The 2012 Festival of London has put the site back on the map.

909.text: There’s so much to do here.

913.text: You’ll also find the BFI’s IMAX Theatre.

916.text: Once you’ve seen a movie here, it’s hard to imagine experiencing cinema anywhere else.

922.text: Keep heading east along the south bank and you’ll pass the arty enclave Gabriel’s Wharf, the Tate Modern, and Shakespeare’s Globe Theatre.

930.text: At Gabriel’s Wharf you can hire bikes and tandems from the London Bicycle Tour Company.

935.text: Children’s seats are free with adult bikes. It’s the most eco-friendly way to explore the area.

943.text: The south bank is the perfect spot for people-watching

945.text: and a short walk across the Millennium Bridge will take you to St Paul’s and other delights north of the river.

953.text: You can also purchase a hop on / hop off ticket from the City Cruises Company for travel along The Thames.

959.text: Pickup points are at piers along the river.

967.text: London has some of the world’s most famous artefacts and treasures housed in its world-class museums.

973.text: However, it’s worth exploring some of the more obscure locations for a true insight into how the city used to feel.

980.text: Dennis Sever’s house is one such very special location.

984.text: The house was created as a time capsule by its fanatical former owner in the style of its original inhabitants,

990.text: a silk-weaving family from the East End.

993.text: It’s now open to the public and a visit will give a sense of how the Huguenots lived through generations from the early 18th Century.

1003.text: The motto of the house is “Aut Visum Aut Non”, - You either see it or you don’t.

1011.text: John Hunter was a pioneer of evidence-based medicine and his anatomical collection was

1016.text: dedicated to The Royal College of Surgeons in 1799.

1022.text: The Hunterian Museum is antiquarian, strange and utterly fascinating.

1028.text: A must-see, but not for the faint-hearted.

1034.text: Sir John Soane’s former home is now London’s favourite museum and it’s packed to the rafters with fascinating artworks and artefacts.

1041.text: Every wall and mantelpiece of this incredible house is cluttered with the treasures and finds of the great architect and innovator.

1052.text: 70 square miles of London are made up of parkland.

1055.text: Head to the lungs of the city for some countryside-like experiences in the heart of the capital.

1061.text: The Bull & Last pub in Highgate, down the hill from the stunning Hampstead Heath, offers freshly-made picnic hampers complete with

1067.text: homemade lemonade and a picnic blanket.

1072.text: Phone in advance to book the wicker-packed delights before heading to the park.

1078.text: Check out the incredible views from the top of Parliament Hill.

1081.text: The Bull & Last is also known for the best roast dinners in London and with open

1085.text: fires and micro-brewed beers it can be a cosy place to while away a cosy afternoon.

1092.text: There’s no better way to take in Hyde Park than on wheels.

1095.text: The park is the spiritual home to London’s skating community.

1099.text: Head to Club Blueroom for skate hire and protective gear.

1104.text: They can also put you in touch with qualified instructors from Skatefresh.

1110.text: Regents Park is home to London Zoo. The zoo works closely with conservation projects around the world.

1116.text: Be sure to check out the squirrel monkeys and the penguins in their spacious beach condo!

1124.text:
Feeding the penguins is still
the highlight of any visit.

1132.text: While you’re in Regents Park, take the water bus to Camden along the canal for a serene route into one of the busiest weekend markets in Europe.

1142.text: London has many magnificent Lidos to choose from but London Field’s Olympic sized pool is by far one of the most impressive.

1150.text:
The Lido sits in the heart of Hackney and is on the doorstep of the artisan’s quarter of
Broadway Market.

1156.text: As the pool is heated, you can swim here whatever the weather!

1164.text: London is fabulous in the sun but if the heavens open, don’t worry, London was built for days like these!

1171.text: Head to one of London’s thriving, independent cinemas.

1174.text: One of the oldest and still the best is The Prince Charles, just off Leicester Square, a real film-lovers cinema.

1181.text:
They run cult classic nights as well
as their popular singalongs!

1189.text: Or for a more opulent indie night at the flicks, head west to Portobello Road where you’ll find the

1193.text: beautifully restored and very luxurious Electric Cinema.

1200.text: All Star Lanes is the best bowling alley in town. An authentic 50’s Americana style experience with great food, cocktails and shoes!

1209.text:
Make like King Pin and forget about
the weather.

1214.text: A beacon of survival and hope, Sir Christopher Wren’s masterpiece,

1218.text: the domed St Paul’s Cathedral still dominates the ever-changing London skyline.

1223.text: There has been a cathedral on this site for over 1,000 years.

1227.text: It’s worth the climb up to the Whispering Gallery.

1229.text:
It’s surreal and shows off the ingenuity
of the acoustic design of this glorious place of worship

1235.text: one of the best places in London to wait out the rain.

1239.text: Grab a post-cathedral cup of tea and a cake at the fantastic Bea’s of Bloomsbury.

1245.text: Of if you’d prefer to bask in the majestic cathedral’s presence for longer,

1248.text: then dine at Jamie Oliver and Adam Perry Lang’s Barbacoa.

1252.text: With stunning views, the restaurant serves the best BBQ’d dishes in town.

1261.text: You can also shelter from the rain with a spot of pampering at the Urban Day Spa at The Mandarin Hotel.

1268.text: Or, for a truly British affair, try the Spa & Barber at Alfred Dunhill in Mayfair.

1274.text: The spa has the look and feel of an exclusive men’s club but there’s nothing stuffy about it.

1279.text: You can book in for a shave while you sip on a tipple from the cellar bar.

1283.text: Although the barbers is men only, the spa treatments are open to women too.

1290.text: If you’re travelling with children there’s plenty to keep the little tykes entertained and amused, even on the dampest of days.

1296.text: All the big museums have plenty to fascinate and occupy adults and children alike

1301.text: and the majority of what’s on offer is free, leaving more money for cake and the gift shop!

1307.text: With activity trails including a trip to see the mummies, The British Museum is perfect for a rainy day out.

1313.text: The museum runs great events for families so be sure to check out what’s on offer on their website.

1320.text: And it’s the gigantic dinosaurs that most impress young and old at The Natural History Museum,

1325.text: an extensive collection of stuffed animals, some now extinct, add to the wonders on show.

1337.text:
Rain or shine, London works in all weather.
This amazing city has something for everyone.

1343.text:
We hope we’ve inspired you to get out there
and get involved.

1346.text: Remember to check out the official tourist website, Visit London, for up-to-date information on what’s happening around town.

1353.text: Have a fabulous trip and thank you for watching.
